This is God handing out punishment to Adam and Eve after they ate from the Tree of Knowlege of Good and Evil. The Bible clearly implies that women are inferior and to be 'ruled over' by men. So, female Christians, what the hell are you thinking?
 
 16 To the woman he said,
 "I will greatly increase your pains in childbearing;
 with pain you will give birth to children.
 Your desire will be for your husband,
 and he will rule over you."

post_info.post_title: Genesis 3:16 - Is this right?  Is this moral?

Well, I would say its not moral, but you also present it somewhat unfairly.
 
 The point is its punishment: this suggests that in a perfect state (ie Eden) women are equal to men, and that their subjugation is part of the Fall. It is bound up with women condemned to pain in childbirth and men condemned to pain in physical work. Basically, its a result of the need to create roles in society due to the hostile world.
 
 In Eden, nothing suggests Eve is inferior. She is sent as a 'helpmate' but this word is most often used of God as the helpmate of man. Moreover, until the creation of Eve, Adam is not referred to with a male term: there's an argument that he is only considered male when he's compared with female.

It depends upon your take on the god of the bible and morality. If one believes thatmorals are fixed in stone and specified by that god, then anything he does cannot be immoral. If you accept that morals are subjective though and judge the passage by modern moral standards, then it is clearly highly immoral.
 
 I'm well and truly in the second camp on this one BTW.

This is God handing out punishment to Adam and Eve after they ate from the Tree of Knowlege of Good and Evil. The Bible clearly implies that women are inferior and to be 'ruled over' by men. So, female Christians, what the hell are you thinking?
 
 16 To the woman he said,
 "I will greatly increase your pains in childbearing;
 with pain you will give birth to children.
 Your desire will be for your husband,
 and he will rule over you."

 
 Isn't "clearly implied" a bit of an oxymoron? What is clear is that God put Adam over Eve. What's implied, and not so clearly, is that this is supossed to be all men over all women forever. That's just one possible interpretation.

Were any of the writers of the Bible female?
 
 In the context (time, culture, civilisation etc.) it was written in, even if the Bible stated outright that men are superior to women, I wouldn't hold it as God's true will.
 
 -Wez

Isn't "clearly implied" a bit of an oxymoron? What is clear is that God put Adam over Eve. What's implied, and not so clearly, is that this is supossed to be all men over all women forever. That's just one possible interpretation.

 Exactly. What happened is that mankind chose to do that which was contrary to God's intentions. You can't just breakout a passage of scripture and denote it as all inclusive. Adam and Eve both made that decision and allowed sin to separate them from God. Keep reading, because God promises them a Saviour. Keep reading - Abraham was given the promise of being blessed and all nations along with him. Does this sound like all of mankind is to be cursed? And what/who was "cursed" anyway? The answer: Satan and the ground - not Adam and Eve. This path that they took was not the path God wanted them to take, but because of free will He allowed it. In that case a social structure had to be developed or total chaos would reign. It is not that man was to rule over women due to God's commandment, but, due to mankind's disobediance, that's the way it has to be for them. So mankind chose that path, not God. God did not make "ruling over Eve" a commandment for all mankind. As a matter of fact it was not a commandment at all, but an observation, so to speak.

Were any of the writers of the Bible female?
 
 In the context (time, culture, civilisation etc.) it was written in, even if the Bible stated outright that men are superior to women, I wouldn't hold it as God's true will.
 
 -Wez

 Very good point, Wez. Kudos. emoticon_xgood

"The Lord God caused a deep sleep to fall upon Adam. As he slept, God took one of his ribs.........and the rib which the Lord God has taken from the man, God made into a woman." Gen: 2:21-22. 
 
 Isn't this myth associated with the idea that man "rules" over woman and she is forever a kind of appendage to man ?

 But, I'm not a newlywed, Waxy.... emoticon_xclown...and don't need no scripture telling me to "rule over" my ol' lady. :p 
 
 It is hard to explain it without going into a very deep discussion that would bore the pants off ya', but extracting scripture without studying the effects of it before and after could get many a "good ol' boy" in trouble.
 
 Sure, snakes crawl on their belly, but I've never seen one "eat dust". I, on the other hand, have eaten dust...literally, but not because I chose to, and certainly not because I'm Ol' Nick. :)
 
 For example: Where Genesis speaks of the "husband ruling the wife", Paul commands mutual submission as the principle of all relationships in the Christian community, including marriage: ...you will submit to one another out of reverence for Christ. (Eph. 5:21)
 
 So, you see, it is essential to read the subsequent verses within the framework of the mutual submission of verse 21 in order to put Genesis into perspective.
 
 Oh, and Waxy, I am always careful... emoticon_rolleyes (No pulling quotes from the Pig Pen - not fair) :p
